[{"detection_name": "Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Injection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "XSS injection vulnerability detected - malicious script patterns found in response", "evidence": "Response status: 200, XSS patterns detected in response data"}]
llm_results:
[{"detection_name": "LLM: xss_injection", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response returns user-controlled fields (firstName, description) containing raw HTML and JavaScript payloads (script tags, , injected attributes). This is strong evidence of stored HTML/JS being delivered by the API. If any client (web UI or admin console) renders these fields into the DOM without proper output encoding or sanitization, an attacker-controlled script would execute in the victim's browser (stored XSS). The issue is high severity because the payloads are stored and returned in normal queries (200 response) and multiple distinct records contain executable markup. Recommended mitigations: ensure server- or client-side output encoding/escaping of data before inserting into HTML, strip or sanitize disallowed HTML tags/attributes (use a safe HTML sanitizer), implement Content Security Policy to limit script execution, and apply input validation and least privilege for any interfaces that render user content. Note: the presence of payloads in the API response is a clear XSS risk vector; actual exploitation depends on whether the consuming client renders these values as HTML without sanitization.", "evidence": "Multiple returned records contain raw HTML/JS in string fields, e.g. {\"id\":\"b2ceb47f-246b-4500-8842-f375e6ac6ac2\",\"description\":\"\"}, {\"id\":\"b6f929fc-e1aa-4cf7-ba4b-8e88d95044f0\",\"description\":\"

Hello World!

\"}, {\"id\":\"639f9e7b-f085-49d5-a7ab-75a952aff50c\",\"firstName\":\"\"}, {\"id\":\"74b9a10e-0548-47e0-9d0a-75afebd2d17b\",\"firstName\":\"\"}, {\"id\":\"74ec59a0-e4c0-4642-8f26-88b1128a8e37\",\"description\":\"\\\"/>\"}", "confidence": 0.9, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "xss_injection", "severity": "HIGH", "confidence": 0.9, "evidence": "Multiple returned records contain raw HTML/JS in string fields, e.g. {\"id\":\"b2ceb47f-246b-4500-8842-f375e6ac6ac2\",\"description\":\"\"}, {\"id\":\"b6f929fc-e1aa-4cf7-ba4b-8e88d95044f0\",\"description\":\"

Hello World!

\"}, {\"id\":\"639f9e7b-f085-49d5-a7ab-75a952aff50c\",\"firstName\":\"\"}, {\"id\":\"74b9a10e-0548-47e0-9d0a-75afebd2d17b\",\"firstName\":\"\"}, {\"id\":\"74ec59a0-e4c0-4642-8f26-88b1128a8e37\",\"description\":\"\\\"/>\"}", "explanation": "The GraphQL response returns user-controlled fields (firstName, description) containing raw HTML and JavaScript payloads (script tags, , injected attributes). This is strong evidence of stored HTML/JS being delivered by the API. If any client (web UI or admin console) renders these fields into the DOM without proper output encoding or sanitization, an attacker-controlled script would execute in the victim's browser (stored XSS). The issue is high severity because the payloads are stored and returned in normal queries (200 response) and multiple distinct records contain executable markup. Recommended mitigations: ensure server- or client-side output encoding/escaping of data before inserting into HTML, strip or sanitize disallowed HTML tags/attributes (use a safe HTML sanitizer), implement Content Security Policy to limit script execution, and apply input validation and least privilege for any interfaces that render user content. Note: the presence of payloads in the API response is a clear XSS risk vector; actual exploitation depends on whether the consuming client renders these values as HTML without sanitization."}}]

[{"detection_name": "Field Suggestions Enabled", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Information Disclosure", "description": "Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure", "evidence": "Found \"did you mean\" in error message - field suggestions are enabled"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "potential", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL error response returns field/argument suggestions and concrete schema identifiers (e.g. 'Did you mean \"friends\"?' and 'Unknown argument \"name\" on field \"Query.getUsers\".', 'Cannot query field \"name\" on type \"User\"'). This leaks schema details that enable an attacker to enumerate valid types, fields and arguments. Such informational disclosure facilitates targeted probing and further attacks (reconnaissance). Recommend disabling detailed validation suggestions in production (e.g., configure GraphQL server to not return suggestion text or stack traces), return generic error messages, and remove stacktrace details from responses.", "evidence": "Error message: \"Cannot query field \\\"fields\\\" on type \\\"User\\\". Did you mean \\\"friends\\\"?\" (plus other validation errors revealing field/argument names)", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "field_suggestions", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Error message: \"Cannot query field \\\"fields\\\" on type \\\"User\\\". Did you mean \\\"friends\\\"?\" (plus other validation errors revealing field/argument names)", "explanation": "The GraphQL error response returns field/argument suggestions and concrete schema identifiers (e.g. 'Did you mean \"friends\"?' and 'Unknown argument \"name\" on field \"Query.getUsers\".', 'Cannot query field \"name\" on type \"User\"'). This leaks schema details that enable an attacker to enumerate valid types, fields and arguments. Such informational disclosure facilitates targeted probing and further attacks (reconnaissance). Recommend disabling detailed validation suggestions in production (e.g., configure GraphQL server to not return suggestion text or stack traces), return generic error messages, and remove stacktrace details from responses."}}]
